title: Love Island: Erin Barnett has her left ovary and Fallopian tubes removed
text:
Erin Barnett has spoken bravely about her lengthy battle with endometriosis and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in the past.

And the Love Island star revealed on Tuesday that she is feeling optimistic about the future after undergoing surgery to remove her left ovary and Fallopian tubes.

Taking to Instagram to share a photo of herself recovering at Waverley Private Hospital, the 24-year-old announced that the pain-relieving surgery was a success.

'I've got my life back': Love Island star Erin Barnett has undergone surgery to remove her left ovary and Fallopian tubes after suffering from chronic endometriosis pain for years

Erin, 24, revealed she had been 'asking, begging and pleading' for the operation for a long time before eventually seeking private treatment.

She wrote: 'I've just woken up from surgery and I can gladly say they successfully removed my Fallopian tubes and left ovary, they also took out some endometriosis! ⁣

'I'm literally pain free as I type this. As in, no crazy ovary pain... because it's no longer in my body! *does happy dance*⁣'

Remember them? Erin (right) starred in the first season of Love Island Australia, where she coupled up with Eden Dally (left)

Erin, a nurse from Melbourne, decided to share her story after being inundated with messages from other women struggling with similar health problems.

Endometriosis causes tissue to grow outside of the uterus, leaving sufferers in chronic pain, while PCOS can lead to ovarian cysts.

Erin explained that it hasn't been easy to get doctors to take her condition seriously.

⁣'As we all know, I've had countless surgeries for PCOS and endometriosis,' she wrote. 'I've been asking, begging and pleading for someone to take out my left ovary because of the pain it causes me daily.'

Living with chronic pain: Erin, a nurse from Melbourne, explained that it hasn't been easy to get doctors to take her condition seriously

WHAT IS ENDOMETRIOSIS? Endometriosis occurs when cells in the lining of the womb are found elsewhere in the body. Each month, these cells react in the same way as those in the womb; building up, breaking down and bleeding. Yet, the blood has no way to escape the body. Symptoms include pain, heavy periods and fatigue, as well as a higher risk of infertility, and bowel and bladder problems. Its cause is unknown but may be genetic, related to problems with the immune system or exposure to chemicals. Treatment focuses on pain relief and improving quality of life, which may include surgery or hormone treatment. Source: Endometriosis UK

Following the procedure, Erin was full of praise for the surgeon who agreed to perform the operation and urged other women to seek help.

She concluded the post with: 'I think I've just gained my life back? WOOHOO!'

Erin starred in the first season of Love Island Australia, where she coupled up with Eden Dally. Following their split, she began dating Mick Russell.
